newsitem.title: USA: Grammys spark sales but music industry still blue.
newsitem.headline: Grammys spark sales but music industry still blue.

text.p: This year's Grammys sparked sales for the big winners and performers at the music awards but the $12 billion industry is still singing the blues.

Indeed, the glitzy Feb. 26 ceremony, which filled up New York's Madison Square Garden and drew thousands of industry professionals to the Big Apple for a week, renewed interest in the music business, where sales have sagged the past year.

But despite all the hoopla, U.S. album sales for the week ended March 2 were flat at 11 million units compared with the week before the show, according to Hartsdale, N.Y.-based Soundscan, which tracks music retail sales.
Several retailers reported little change in traffic.

"If we noticed anything at all, it was slight. It was steady but nothing remarkable," said Elliott Cobb, treasurer of the 265-store, California-based Wherehouse Entertainment chain, which recently emerged from bankruptcy.

But other retailers said the event was a plus, particularly since the 39th annual Grammy awards endorsed an array of artists popular with several generations -- from 70-year-old Tony Bennett, winning the best traditional pop vocal performance award, to 14-year-old LeAnn Rimes, who was named best new artist of the year.
"The Grammys have a big sales impact because it covers all the genres," said Dick Odette, vice president of merchandising for Musicland Stores Corp.
"There's a lot of exposure, even for the nominees. And if you're a performer on the show, that's even more of an accelerator," said Odette. "A performance at the Grammys wins at the cash register."

Indeed, the awards show featured a gospel-oriented medley from the "Waiting to Exhale" soundtrack, performed by Whitney Houston, Mary Blige and Brandy, which showed a spike in sales. Sales of the soundtrack jumped to 8,000 units from 5,000 the week earlier.

Other big beneficiaries was Celine Dion's "Falling Into You", which won best album of the year. Sales of the album, on Sony Corp.'s 550 Music label, soared to 119,232 from 80,575 units the week before, according to Soundscan.
The album has sold 7.1 million copies since its March 1996 release.
Sony was a big winner among the world's six major labels, boasting victories by Dion, as well as Bennett and rhythm and blues band The Fugees on its Columbia label.
The best song of the year award went to "Change the World" on Time Warner Inc.'s Reprise label by rock legend Eric Clapton.
Sales of "Odelay", the hit album by alternative artist Beck, who won two Grammys this year, rose to 36,168 units from 18,964.
"I'd expect sales to continue to stay strong based on post-Grammy media interest and exposure," said Dennis Dennehy, spokesman for Seagram Co.'s Geffen label, which distributes Beck.
"Beck picked up before the Grammys based on his nomination and then picked up again afterwards," said Henry Droz, who heads distribution for Seagram's Universal, which includes the Geffen label.
"There was a pickup in overall music sales due to renewed public interest in music," said Droz. "Aside from Beck, we didn't win that many Grammys, but our business picked up.
"The Grammys always help business, sometimes a great deal and sometimes marginally. I'd call this year average."
